questions.text: Part A (AB or BC): Graphing calculator required

General Scoring Notes
The model solution is presented using standard mathematical notation.

Answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. Answers given as a decimal approximation should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Within each individual free-response question, at most one point is not earned for inappropriate rounding.

A customer at a gas station is pumping gasoline into a gas tank. The rate of flow of gasoline is modeled by a differentiable functionfff, wheref(t)f(t)f(t)is measured in gallons per second andtttis measured in seconds since pumping began. Selected values off(t)f(t)f(t)are given in the table.

(a) Using correct units, interpret the meaning of∫60135f(t)dt\int_{60}^{135} f(t) , dt∫60135​f(t)dtin the context of the problem. Use a right Riemann sum with the three subintervals[60,90][60, 90][60,90],[90,120][90, 120][90,120], and[120,135][120, 135][120,135]to approximate the value of∫60135f(t)dt\int_{60}^{135} f(t) , dt∫60135​f(t)dt.

• A response that presents a correct value with accompanying work that shows the three products in the Riemann sum but does not show all six of the factors and/or the sum process, does not earn the second point but does earn the third point. For example, responses of either4.5+3.0+0.754.5 + 3.0 + 0.754.5+3.0+0.75or(0.15)(30),0.1(30),0.05(15)→8.25(0.15)(30), 0.1(30), 0.05(15) \rightarrow 8.25(0.15)(30),0.1(30),0.05(15)→8.25earn the third point but not the second.
• A response that presents an answer of only 8.25 does not earn either the second or third point.

• A response that provides a completely correct left Riemann sum with accompanying work,f(60)(30)+f(90)(30)+f(120)(15)=9f(60)(30) + f(90)(30) + f(120)(15) = 9f(60)(30)+f(90)(30)+f(120)(15)=9, or(0.1)(30)+(0.15)(30)+(0.1)(15)(0.1)(30) + (0.15)(30) + (0.1)(15)(0.1)(30)+(0.15)(30)+(0.1)(15)earns 1 of the last 2 points. A response with any errors or missing factors in a left Riemann sum earns neither of the last 2 points.
(b) Must there exist a value ofccc, for60<c<12060 < c < 12060<c<120, such thatf′(c)=0f'(c) = 0f′(c)=0? Justify your answer.
By the Mean Value Theorem, there must exist accc, for60<c<12060 < c < 12060<c<120, such thatf′(c)=0f'(c) = 0f′(c)=0.

Scoring notes:
• To earn the first point a response must present eitherf(120)−f(60)=0f(120) - f(60) = 0f(120)−f(60)=0,0.1−0.1=00.1 - 0.1 = 00.1−0.1=0(perhaps as the numerator of a quotient), orf(60)=f(120)f(60) = f(120)f(60)=f(120).
• To earn the second point a response must:
  o have earned the first point,
  o state thatfffis continuous becausefffis differentiable (or equivalent), and
  o answer “yes” in some way.
• A response may reference either the Mean Value Theorem or Rolle’s Theorem.
• A response that references the Intermediate Value Theorem cannot earn the second point.
(c) The rate of flow of gasoline, in gallons per second, can also be modeled by

g(t)=(t500)cos⁡((t120)2)g(t) = \left(\frac{t}{500}\right)\cos\left(\left(\frac{t}{120}\right)^2\right)g(t)=(500t​)cos((120t​)2)for0≤t≤1500 \leq t \leq 1500≤t≤150. Using this model, find the average rate of flow of gasoline over the time interval0≤t≤1500 \leq t \leq 1500≤t≤150. Show the setup for your calculations.
The average rate of flow of gasoline, in gallons per second, is 0.096 (or 0.095).
(d) Using the modelgggdefined in part (c), find the value ofg′(140)g'(140)g′(140). Interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of the problem.
The rate at which gasoline is flowing into the tank is decreasing at a rate of 0.005 (or 0.004) gallon per second per second at timet=140t = 140t=140seconds.
